doc.field: High resolution (0.01° x 0.01°)Gulf of Mexico bathymetric grid, version 2.0 generated in February 2013. Data are in NetCDF-3 classic format. Luis Zamudio-Lopez (NRL, Luis.Zamudio@nrlssc.navy.mil) kindly offered an initial 1=100°(~1000 m) bathymetric grid for the region. This grid has been computationally modified and substantially hand edited (a) to better match the shoreline definition, (b) fill the voids in the water depths and (c) if possible, to more accurate represent the interpolated water depths. The final numerical grid conforms to the 1=25°(~4000 m) North Atlantic HYCOM computational domain, where they are both matched at 76:40 oW longitude. Data used in the development of the new grid include GSHHS: A Global Self-consistent, Hierarchical, High-resolution Shoreline Database, GEBCO 30 arc-sec global grid, a global high resolution 911x944m bathymetry (GMRT: The Global Multi-Resolution Topography) ,and the National Geophysical Data Center’s (NGDC) 6 arc-sec U.S. Coastal Relief Model database, volumes: 2, 3, 4 and 5.
Gulf of Mexico High-Resolution (0.01° x 0.01°) Bathymetric Grid - Version 2.0, February 2013

R1.x138.080-0014-metadata.xml eng; USA utf8 dataset Panagiotis Velissariou Florida State University Assistant in Research 850-645-9832 Tallahassee FL 323062741 USA pvelissariou@coaps.fsu.edu pointOfContact 2016-03-31T14:54:36-05:00 ISO 19115-2 Geographic Information - Metadata - Part 2: Extensions for Imagery and Gridded Data ISO 19115-2:2009(E) https://data.gulfresearchinitiative.org/metadata/R1.x138.080:0014 Gulf of Mexico High-Resolution (0.01° x 0.01°) Bathymetric Grid - Version 2.0, February 2013 2014-03-18 publication High resolution (0.01° x 0.01°)Gulf of Mexico bathymetric grid, version 2.0 generated in February 2013. Data are in NetCDF-3 classic format. Luis Zamudio-Lopez (NRL, Luis.Zamudio@nrlssc.navy.mil) kindly offered an initial 1=100°(~1000 m) bathymetric grid for the region. This grid has been computationally modified and substantially hand edited (a) to better match the shoreline definition, (b) fill the voids in the water depths and (c) if possible, to more accurate represent the interpolated water depths. The final numerical grid conforms to the 1=25°(~4000 m) North Atlantic HYCOM computational domain, where they are both matched at 76:40 oW longitude. Data used in the development of the new grid include GSHHS: A Global Self-consistent, Hierarchical, High-resolution Shoreline Database, GEBCO 30 arc-sec global grid, a global high resolution 911x944m bathymetry (GMRT: The Global Multi-Resolution Topography) ,and the National Geophysical Data Center’s (NGDC) 6 arc-sec U.S. Coastal Relief Model database, volumes: 2, 3, 4 and 5. Recent research goals for the Gulf of Mexico region (e.g., Deep-C) require the use of a more accurate and of higher resolution bathymetry. This bathymetry will be an integral part of the Gulf of Mexico Coupled Regional Modeling System (GoM-CRMS) being developed at the Center for Ocean-Atmospheric Prediction Studies (COAPS). To develop a regional 3D Earth System Model that includes interfacial exchange processes between sediment, water, and atmosphere; biogeochemical processes, the transport of organisms, and the effects of petroleum hydrocarbons on all of these processes. completed Panagiotis Velissariou Florida State University Assistant in Research 850-645-9832 Tallahassee FL 32306-2741 USA pvelissariou@coaps.fsu.edu pointOfContact Numerical Modeling Physical Oceanography Bathymetry theme Gulf of Mexico place eng;
